_prev_prog_3.Description: Beef Packers, Inc. has updated their unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program.  The program is in compliance with CaliforniaA?s Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements.  At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAA?s A?Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous MaterialsA? standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, A?Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials,A? and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119).  This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



for



Cargill Meat Solutions Corporation

3115 S. Fig Avenue

Fresno, CA 93706

(559) 268-5586

FAX (559) 486-6929



The Cargill Meat Solutions - Fresno, CA primary business is processing wholesale distribution of meat products for human consumption. The facility operates processes an ammonia refrigeration system as part of the process to keep products and raw materials fresh. Ammonia is recirculated in the system as a liquid and gas depending on system operating pressures and temperatures This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP), CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 and the California Process Safety Management Program, CCR Title 8, Section 5189 as enforced by the local Certified Unified Program Agency and the Fed/EPA. In addition 40 CFR 68.130 lists anhydrous ammonia as a hazardous chemical subject to Federal RMP regulation with a threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs at the Main Plant Process the refrigeration system inventory exceeds the threshold.  The West Coast Packer process is under the 10,000 lbs threshold but applicable to CalOSHA and CalARP therefore is documented as a Program 2 in the Federal RMP program. 



The RMP was resubmitted in September 10, 2020 to meet the five-year anniversary date by which you must next update your RMP.



Facility release modeling was performed using EPA's modeling program RMP*Comp in addition to ALOHA software and Marplot. The methodologies reported in CDX reflect conservative modeling approaches to meet the endpoint criteria. The both worst-case scenarios are based on the High-Pressure Vessel as that vessel could potentially hold the largest quantity of ammonia. No passive or administrative controls were considered for the release scenarios. For the worst-case scenarios, smaller quantities handled at higher process temperature or pressure were considered. The report and supporting information contained herein only specify the final select

ed worst-case scenarios.



Both alternate release scenarios are based on oil draining. Other alternate cases were considered including, overpressure situation from a pressure relief valve, vessel overfilling, over pressurization scenarios, pipe ruptures and material handling and transfer hoses. Alternate release scenarios including shipping container mishandling, breakage, or puncturing that could lead to a spill were not considered because the facility does not handle shipping containers containing anhydrous ammonia.





The facility has developed and implemented a Process Safety Management Program (PSM) in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 and prepared a unified program based on PSM to meet CalARP and CalOSHA obligations so that it meshes more closely with general Cargill Meat Solutions Corporation business practices as well.  The facility's PSM program includes provisions for process hazard analyses, training, standard operating procedures, management of change, pre-start up safety reviews, safe work practices, inspections, testing, maintenance, compliance audits, and contractor qualifications. All significant changes to the system are reviewed in accordance with the PSM/RMP management of change provisions in the facility's plan. Qualified outside contractors are used for construction and major repairs or modifications to the system. The facility has an emergency action plan in place and conducts periodic response drills and coordinates with the local fire department and LEPC. The facility is committed to continually improving safety through program implementation and execution. The facility has not experienced a release incident that meets the EPA's 5 Year Accident Reporting criteria involving ammonia that resulted in any on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or that resulted in any offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental d

amage. 



The system is equipped with a series of redundant failsafe devices, sensors, and overrides. In the event a malfunction occurs that could result in an ammonia release, these protective devices shut the system down. The system can't be restarted until the cause of the shutdown is identified and corrected.  The refrigeration system can also be manually shut down via an emergency switch located outside the East and West machinery room in addition to the West Coast Packers machinery room.



DESCRIPTION OF AMMONIA SYSTEM



The Cargill Meat Solutions Corporation is a commercial beef slaughter house and processing facility. The Main Plant Processing System provides refrigeration capacity to the Kill Floor area, Offal Storage rooms, Chill Coolers and Boning Rooms. The Kill Floor is cooled by two packaged roof mounted ACUair blower coil units. There are four Carcass Coolers and two Offal Storage rooms that are cooled by ceiling mounted fan coil units. There are five Boning Rooms that are cooled by a combination of three packaged roof mounted ACUair blower coil units and ceiling mounted fan coil units. A computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability. 



High pressure liquid from a high pressure receiver is piped to two liquid recirculators through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves and expansions valves. From there, low pressure liquid is piped to each cold room, where it passes through a solenoid valve and hand expansion valve and into evaporator coils. Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator coils. Low pressure and temperature gas and overfeed liquid passes through regulators or check valves and is returned to one of two pumped liquid recirculators located in the engine room. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the accumulator and the suction gas is piped to the screw compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled e

ated on the Cargill Meat Solutions Corporation property. This is a separate process with a dedicated ammonia system that provides cooling to a single packaging room. A ground mounted ACUair unit provides room cooling. A computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability. 



High pressure liquid from a high pressure receiver is piped to a liquid recirculator through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves and expansions valves. From there, low pressure liquid is piped to the ACUair unit, where it passes through solenoid valves and hand expansion valves and into evaporator coils. Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator coils. Low pressure and temperature gas and overfeed liquid passes through regulators or check valves and is returned to the pumped liquid recirculator located in the engine area. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the accumulator and the suction gas is piped to the screw or the reciprocating compressor which elevates the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver. Excess liquid from the liquid recirculator is pumped to a transfer vessel where the liquid transfers into the high pressure receiver by gravity.



The West Coast Packers process was built in 2004. This area is served by an ammonia refrigeration system designed and installed by professional refrigeration engineers in accordance with industry standards at the time. It was also built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a water diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set

vaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to a thermosyphon vessel and from the thermosyphon vessel it returns to the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel is supplied to the oil coolers on each screw compressor. High temperature liquid is evaporated in the oil cooler and a combination of high temperature gas and liquid is returned to the thermosyphon vessel by thermosyphon action. Excess liquid from the liquid recirculators is pumped to a transfer vessel where the liquid transfers into the high pressure receiver by gravity.

 

The Kill Floor, Offal rooms, and two Chill Coolers were new facilities built from 1999 to 2001. The other Chill Coolers the Boning areas were remodels of an existing meat processing facility. This work was done from 2001 to 2004. All areas are served by an ammonia refrigeration system designed and installed by professional refrigeration engineers in accordance with industry standards at the time. It was also built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a water diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. In addition, ammonia detectors are located throughout the facility, and will shut down equipment if ammonia is detected. Lastly, an emergency dump box contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.



The ammonia system at the Main Plant consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected. Therefore, the main facility is treated as a single process.



West Coast Packers Plant is a case ready facility loc

point. In addition, ammonia detectors are located in the grinding room, and will shut down equipment if ammonia is detected. Lastly, an emergency dump box contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.



The Main Plant Processing and West Coast Packers ammonia systems consists of vessels, pipe, and equipment which are interconnected. Therefore, the Cargill Meat Solutions Corporation has two (2) ammonia refrigeration processes, Main Plant Process (EPA RMP Program 3) and West Coast Packers Process (EPA RMP Program 2).
